text:
Williamsburg Bridge across the East River under construction. It was begun November 7, 1896 and opened December 19, 1903. Construction cost £15,091,497, and land £9,096,593. Totaling £24,188,090.

B. H. Hellmich
no date
title: Bridges - Williamsburg Bridge - East River - [Construction.]
New East River Bridge

text:
The Williamsburg (East River) Bridge under construction as viewed southeastward from the Manhattan shore. In the foreground is the area that will be cleared (1939) for the East River Drive. The R. Hoe and Company foundry on the right will shortly be removed.

About 1903-4

Ewing Galloway
title: Bridges - Williamsburg Bridge - [R. Hoe and Company.]

text:
Williamsburg Bridge Plaza, viewing westward between Broadway (left) and South 4th Street (right). The Broadway Elevated Line is seen serpentining its way onto the Williamsburg Bridge.

The domed structure beyond the Sapolio sign is the Williamsburg Savings Bank Building. In the foreground is seen one of the main trolley termini of Brooklyn. The white marble building (car in front thereof) in the right center of the view, houses the Williamsburg Trust Co.

About, 190

Urbrock Collection

April 11, 1928.

text:
Grand Street, north side, east from and including Sheriff, to and including Columbia Streets. Also shown is Sheriff Street, east side, north from and including Grand, to and including Delancey Streets. In the background on Delancey Street, is the Williamsburg Bridge.

About 1930.

Joseph P. Day.

(1) Grand Street, north side, between Sheriff and Columbia Streets. (Street front not shown). Also shown is Broome Street north side, east from but not including Sheriff, to and including Columbia Streets. Included also is Columbia Street, east side, south from and including Broome, to, but not including Grand Streets. The view shows in the foreground, work in progress for the erection of a model apartment house on the site of the old R. text:
A general view northward from the Williamsburg Bridge, showing on the horizon the 42nd Street-Midtown skyline. From left to right the structures are, the Consolidated Edison Co, Metropolitan Life Insurance Co, New York Life Insurance Co, Empire State, No. 10 E. 40th Street, No. 500 Fifth Avenue, R. C. A. (under construction), Lincoln, Chanin, Chrysler, Hotel Waldorf Astoria (twin spires), General Electric, News and Hotel Woodstock Buildings. View No. 3 centers the Empire State Building between the iron cross ribs of the bridge.

September 18, 1932
Views: 1, 2 and 3

P. L. Sperr
title: General view - [Lower East side of Manhattan - Williamsburg Bridge (North).]

text:

July 31, 1934.

No's. 6,8,10,12,14, and 12 Broome Street, at, adjoining and west of the N. W. corner of Tompkins Street. Also shown is Tompkins Street, west side, north from Broome to Delancey Streets. Note the East River (Williamsburg) Bridge arching Tompkins Street. These buildings are numbered as above. The corner block is 6 to 14 inclusive.

East River, shoreline, east from pier 44 (Jackson Street), showing Corlears Hook Park and the Hecker Flour factory building where the river makes a sharp bend in a northerly direction. Also shown is the Williamsburg Bridge and the shore of the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn (right background).

September 16, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.
title: East River - Shore and skyline of lower Manhattan - South Ferry - Williamsburg Bridge - Jackson Street (East) - Corlears Hook.

January 26, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

P. L. Sperr.

East River Drive, south from East 11th Street. The piles of rock and sand shown on the left will be used to fill in the shoreline at this point. Across same, in the background is the Williamsburg Bridge, connecting Delancey Street, Manhattan with Brooklyn. No. 2 of this set is in the same direction from East 5th Street.

June 15, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

East River Drive, south from East 11th Street. The piles of rock and sand shown on the left will be used to fill in the shoreline at this point. Across same, in the background is the Williamsburg Bridge, connecting Delancey Street, Manhattan with Brooklyn. No. 2 of this set is in the same direction from East 5th Street.

June 15, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

East River Drive, (extreme right) south from about East 12th Street, showing the area east of same being filled in. Shown in the background, at Delancey Street, is the Williamsburg Bridge that crosses the East River to Brooklyn. Nos. 2 and 3 of this set are southward from 11th Street. Note the bulkheads and the former pier stumps.

June 4, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

East River Drive, (extreme right) south from about East 12th Street, showing the area east of same being filled in. Shown in the background, at Delancey Street, is the Williamsburg Bridge that crosses the East River to Brooklyn. Nos. 2 and 3 of this set are southward from 11th Street. Note the bulkheads and the former pier stumps.

June 4, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

East River Drive, (extreme right) south from about East 12th Street, showing the area east of same being filled in. Shown in the background, at Delancey Street, is the Williamsburg Bridge that crosses the East River to Brooklyn. Nos. 2 and 3 of this set are southward from 11th Street. Note the bulkheads and the former pier stumps.

June 4, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

Exterior (Marginal) Street, south from East 15th to 14th Streets, showing at the latter point a coal crane of the Consolidated Gas Co. (plant on the right). This street will be incorporated in the new East River Drive. In the background appears the Williamsburg Bridge to Brooklyn (left).

September 1937.

George D. Chinn.

(1) Mangin Street, north from Grand Street. Shown transversing the street at Delancey Street, is the Williamsburg Bridge.

P. L. Sperr.

P. L. Sperr.

Monroe Street, east from and including Jackson to Grand Streets. A portion of Brooklyn appears under the Williamsburg Bridge roadway.

March 23, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

The 5 story tenement at the left, No. 275 Monroe St., at the N. E. corner of Jackson St., is to be razed according to the N. Y. Sun of March 27, 1939. To the east of same is a 4 story factory (No. 293-7) that is to go also.

Rivington Street, east to South Street. Looking southwards and showing the Williamsburg Bridge and the beginning of the East River Drive.

Manhattan Highways Comm.

Williamsburg Bridge: Looking north (view 1) and south from the Manhattan side of the East River.

title: Bridges - Williamsburg Bridge - [East River - Manhattan end.]

text:
Goerck Street, east side, south from Stanton Street towards the Williamsburg Bridge (seen at Delancey Street). Note the vacant lots in the foreground block that are a direct result of the enforcement of the multiple housing law which necessitated minimum requirements. The operators evidently found it cheaper to demolish than to conform.

June 29, 1938.

P.L. Sperr

Recreations and Hobbies: Swimming off Corlears Hook. At the left is the Heckers Flour Co. plant, obstructing a view of the Manhattan landing of the Williamsburg Bridge. The Brooklyn sector that identifies this structure is in the background. The U. S. Navy Yard there, if shown, would be on the right.

1938-9

Alexander Alland
title: Recreation and hobbies - [Swimming off Corlears Hook.]

text:
Cherry Street, east from and across Gouverneur Streets, showing demolition of structures between this point and the Williamsburg Bridge (background). The structures being demolished at this date comprise the Provident (Fidelity) Warehouses. At the left (N. W. corner) is a small park that has recently been added to P. S. No. 31 and is at its rear. Note the W. P. A. sign on the work shack; demolition being under their auspices.

August 2, 1939
Views: 1 and 2

P. L. Sperr

Cherry Street, east from and across Gouverneur Streets, showing demolition of structures between this point and the Williamsburg Bridge (background). The structures being demolished at this date comprise the Provident (Fidelity) Warehouses. At the left (N. W. corner) is a small park that has recently been added to P. S. No. 31 and is at its rear. Note the W. P. A. sign on the work shack; demolition being under their auspices.

August 2, 1939
Views: 1 and 2

P. L. Sperr

Cherry Street, east from and across Gouverneur Street, showing demolition in progress for a general slum clearance project, under the joint auspices of the City and the U. S. government. These sites will be improved by the New East River Drive, Vladeck Houses and Vladeck City Houses. At the left is a small park at the rear of P. S. No. 31. The stable opened to view in No. 3 is No. 46 Scammel Street. To the rear are buildings of the Provident (lately, Fidelity) Warehouse Co. These are all to come down.

June 1, 1939
Views 1, 2, 3

P. L. Sperr

Cherry Street, east from and across Gouverneur Street, showing demolition in progress for a general slum clearance project, under the joint auspices of the City and the U. S. government. These sites will be improved by the New East River Drive, Vladeck Houses and Vladeck City Houses. At the left is a small park at the rear of P. S. No. 31. The stable opened to view in No. 3 is No. 46 Scammel Street. To the rear are buildings of the Provident (lately, Fidelity) Warehouse Co. These are all to come down.

P. L. Sperr

Cherry Street, east from a point to the east of Scammel Street, viewing towards Corlears Hook Park and the Williamsburg Bridge. The tenement at the right is No. 391-3 and it adjoins the S.E. corner of Scammel Street. To the east of same are buildings housing the Old Dutch Mustard Co. These comprise No's. 395 to 405. The latter is a 4 story structure formerly occupied by the New York City Drug Mill. The vacant lot (formerly No's. 407 to 419 inclusive) has recently been cleared of tenements and is at this date, a parking lot.

April 23, 1939
Views: 1 and 2

P. L. Sperr

Cherry Street, east from a point to the east of Scammel Street, viewing towards Corlears Hook Park and the Williamsburg Bridge. The latter is a 4 story structure formerly occupied by the New York City Drug Mill. The vacant lot (formerly No's. 407 to 419 inclusive) has recently been cleared of tenements and is at this date, a parking lot.

East River Drive, west across Gouverneur Slip, showing details of the construction of this new vehicular thoroughfare. This necessitated the removal of a stretch a block wide, extending between South and Front Streets. At the right is Gouverneur Hospital.

Goerck Street, south from Stanton Street, viewing towards Delancey Street and it's overhanging Williamsburg Bridge. Note the various clearances in the foreground block that extends to Rivington Street. Illegal and abandoned tenements formerly stood there. The several City and Government agencies co-operated in their removal.

May 12, 1939

original_title: Manhattan: East River Drive - Montgomery Street
text:
East River Drive, east from a point below Montgomery Street, showing constructional details of this new vehicular thoroughfare. The entire block between Front and South Streets has been cleared permitting this to continue as a marginal thoroughfare. On the left is Gouverneur Hospital at Gouverneur Slip. Preceding the Williamsburg Bridge is the open area forming Corlears Hook Park.

April 7, 1940
No's. 1-2-3

P. L. Sperr
